question: A 54-year-old African-American man with a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia undergoes a treadmill exercise test using the standard Bruce protocol. He stops at 11 minutes 14 seconds because of fatigue, at a peak heart rate of 152 beats/minute and peak systolic blood pressure of \(200\mathrm{mm}\mathrm{Hg}\) . The diastolic blood pressure declines by \(5\mathrm{mm}\) Hg during exercise. During recovery, the systolic blood pressure decreases to \(15\mathrm{mm}\mathrm{Hg}\) below his pre- exercise pressure. There are no ischemic changes on the ECG during or after exercise. Which of the following is correct?

options.A: His peak systolic blood pressure during exercise exceeds that normally observed.
options.B: The change in diastolic blood pressure during exercise is indicative of significant coronary artery disease
options.C: This test is nondiagnostic owing to an inadequate peak heart rate
options.D: These results are consistent with a low prognostic risk of a coronary event
options.E: The postexercise reduction in systolic blood pressure is suggestive of severe coronary artery disease

question: Which of the following statements regarding the second heart sound \((S_{2})\) is TRUE?

options.A: Earlier closure of the pulmonic valve with inspiration results in physiologic splitting of \(S_{2}\)
options.B: Right bundle branch block results in widened splitting of \(S_{2}\)
options.C: Paradoxical splitting of \(S_{2}\) is the auscultatory hallmark of an ostium secundum atrial septal defect
options.D: Fixed splitting of \(S_{2}\) is expected in patients with a right ventricular electronically paced rhythm
options.E: Severe pulmonic valvular stenosis is associated with a loud \(P_{2}\)

question: A state-of-the-art blood test has been developed for the rapid, noninvasive diagnosis of coronary artery disease. The assay has a sensitivity of \(90\%\) and a specificity of \(90\%\) for the detection of at least one coronary stenosis of greater than \(70\%\) . In which of the following scenarios is the blood test likely to be of most value to the clinician?

options.A: A 29-year-old man with exertional chest pain who has no cardiac risk factors
options.B: A 41-year-old asymptomatic premenopausal woman
options.C: A 78-year-old diabetic woman with exertional chest pain who underwent two-vessel coronary stenting 6 weeks ago
options.D: A 62-year-old man with exertional chest pain who has hypertension, dyslipidemia, and a two-pack-per-day smoking history
options.E: A 68-year-old man with chest discomfort at rest accompanied by \(2\mathrm{mm}\) of ST-segment depression in the inferior leads on the ECG

question: A murmur is auscultated during routine examination of an 18- year- old asymptomatic college student, at the second left intercostal space, close to the sternum. The murmur is crescendo- decrescendo, is present throughout systole and diastole, and peaks simultaneously with \(S_{2}\) . It does not change with position or rotation of the head. Which of the following best describes this murmur?

options.A: This is a continuous murmur, most likely a venous hum commonly heard in adolescents
options.B: This is a continuous murmur resulting from mixed aortic valve disease
options.C: This is a continuous murmur due to a congenital shunt, likely a patent ductus arteriosus
options.D: Continuous murmurs of this type can only be congenital; murmurs due to acquired arteriovenous connections are purely systolic

question: Unequal upper extremity arterial pulsations would be unlikely in which of the following disorders?

options.A: Aortic dissection
options.B: Takayasu disease
options.C: Supravalvular aortic stenosis
options.D: Subclavian artery atherosclerosis
options.E: Subvalvular aortic stenosis

question: A 58- year- old woman with metastatic breast cancer presents with exertional dyspnea and is found to have a large circumferential pericardial effusion, jugular venous distention, and hypotension. Which of the following echocardiographic signs is likely present?

options.A: Collapse of the right ventricle throughout systole
options.B: Exaggerated decrease in tricuspid inflow velocity during inspiration
options.C: Exaggerated decrease in mitral inflow velocity during inspiration
options.D: Exaggerated increase in left ventricular outflow tract velocity during inspiration
options.E: Markedly increased E/A ratio of the transmital Doppler velocity profile

question: Which of the following statements about pulsus paradoxus is correct?

options.A: Inspiration in normal individuals results in a decline of systolic arterial pressure of up to \(18\mathrm{mm}\mathrm{Hg}\)
options.B: Accurate determination of pulsus paradoxus requires intra-arterial pressure measurement
options.C: Pulsus paradoxus is unlikely to be present in patients with advanced aortic regurgitation, even in the presence of tamponade
options.D: Pulsus paradoxus is common in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

question: A 57- year- old man with a history of hypertension and elevated low- density lipoprotein cholesterol presents to the emergency room with the acute onset of substernal chest pressure, dyspnea, and diaphoresis. His blood pressure is \(158 / 96\mathrm{mm}\mathrm{Hg}\) and the heart rate is 92 beats/minute. Physical examination reveals clear lung fields and no cardiac gallop or murmurs. The ECG shows sinus rhythm with a prominent R wave in lead \(\mathrm{V}_2\) , \(0.5\mathrm{mm}\) of ST elevation in lead III, and \(2\mathrm{mm}\) of horizontal ST depression in leads \(\mathrm{V}_1\) to \(\mathrm{V}_3\) . Which of the following would be diagnostically useful to plan a course of action?

options.A: Repeat the ECG with right-sided precordial leads
options.B: Repeat the ECG with \(\mathrm{V}_7\) to \(\mathrm{V}_9\) leads
options.C: Await results of serum cardiac biomarkers
options.D: Obtain a chest computed tomography to assess for pulmonary embolism

question: Which of the following combinations does NOT have the potential for significant pharmacologic interaction?

options.A: Simvastatin and erythromycin
options.B: Sildenafil and nitroglycerin
options.C: Pravastatin and ketoconazole
options.D: Cyclosporine and St. John's wort
options.E: Digoxin and verapamil

question: It would be reasonable and safe to order a treadmill exercise stress test for a patient with which of the following conditions?

options.A: Symptomatic hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy
options.B: Advanced aortic stenosis
options.C: Acute myocarditis
options.D: Abdominal aortic aneurysm with transverse diameter of \(5.5\mathrm{cm}\)
options.E: Unstable angina

question: An 82- year- old man with a history of coronary artery disease underwent coronary artery bypass grafting surgery 6 years ago. He presents to the emergency department with right upper quadrant abdominal pain and anorexia. His medications include aspirin, metoprolol succinate, and atorvastatin. Physical examination, laboratory assessment, and abdominal ultrasound confirm the diagnosis of acute cholecystitis. The patient has normal vital signs, and his pain is improved with analgesia. The cardiovascular consultation service is called to perform perioperative risk assessment prior to cholecystectomy. The patient lives with his spouse in a two- floor home. He does not routinely exercise but is able to walk up one flight of stairs to his bedroom each night without chest pain or shortness of breath. He denies recent current angina or dyspnea on exertion. There has been no orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, or peripheral edema. The cardiovascular examination is normal, and his ECG in the emergency room is unchanged from a prior tracing 4 months earlier. What is the next appropriate step?

options.A: Recommend percutaneous cholecystostomy rather than laparoscopic or open cholecystectomy due to the high risk of surgery
options.B: Recommend vasodilator stress myocardial perfusion imaging prior to surgery
options.C: Recommend that he proceed with surgery with no further cardiac testing
options.D: Stop metoprolol succinate prior to surgery

question: A 56- year- old asymptomatic man with a history of hypertension and cigarette smoking is referred for an exercise treadmill test. After 7 minutes on the standard Bruce protocol, he is noted to have \(1\mathrm{mm}\) of flat ST- segment depression in leads II, III, and aVF. He stops exercising at 9 minutes because of leg fatigue and breathlessness. The peak heart rate is \(85\%\) of the maximum predicted for his age. The ST segments return to baseline by 1 minute into recovery. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: This test is conclusive for severe stenosis of the proximal right coronary artery
options.B: His risk of death due to an acute myocardial infarction during the next year is greater than \(50\%\)
options.C: He should proceed directly to coronary angiography
options.D: The test predicts a \(25\%\) risk of cardiac events over the next 5 years, most likely the development of angina
options.E: This is likely a false-positive test

question: In which of the following clinical scenarios do ST- segment depressions during standard exercise testing increase the diagnostic probability of significant coronary artery disease?

options.A: A 56-year-old man with left bundle branch block and a family history of premature coronary disease
options.B: A 45-year-old woman with diabetes and hypertension, with left ventricular hypertrophy on her baseline ECG
options.C: A 76-year-old woman with new external dyspnea, a history of cigarette smoking, and a normal baseline ECG
options.D: A 28-year-old woman with pleuritic left- sided chest pain after a gymnastics class
options.E: A 63-year-old man with exertional dyspnea on beta blocker, digoxin, and nitrate therapies

question: Which of the following statements regarding cardiac catheterization is TRUE?

options.A: The risk of a major complication from cardiac catheterization is \(2.0\%\) to \(2.5\%\)
options.B: The incidence of contrast-induced nephrotoxicity in patients with renal dysfunction is decreased with intravenous administration of mannitol before and after the procedure
options.C: High osmolar nonionic contrast agents demonstrate a reduced incidence of adverse hemodynamic reactions compared with low osmolar ionic contrast agents
options.D: One French unit (F), a measurement of catheter diameter, is equivalent to \(0.33\mathrm{mm}\)
options.E: Retrograde left-sided heart catheterization is generally a safe procedure in patients with tilting-disc prosthetic aortic valves

question: A 75- year- old woman was brought urgently to the cardiac catheterization laboratory in the setting of an acute ST- elevation myocardial infarction. She had presented with chest pain, epigastric discomfort, and nausea. Physical examination was pertinent for diaphoresis, heart rate 52 beats/minute, blood pressure \(85 / 50\mathrm{mmHg}\) , jugular venous distention, and slight bilateral pulmonary rales. Coronary angiography demonstrated ostial occlusion of a dominant right coronary artery, without significant left- sided coronary artery disease. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: Isolated infarction of the right ventricle, without left ventricular involvement, is likely
options.B: ST-segment elevation in leads \(\mathrm{V}_1\) and \(\mathrm{V}_2\) would be expected to accompany inferior ST elevation
options.C: The abnormal heart rate and blood pressure are likely a consequence of vagal stimulation
options.D: ST-segment depression is expected in lead \(\mathrm{V}_4\mathrm{R}\)

question: Using Doppler echocardiography, the following values are obtained in a patient with a restrictive ventricular septal defect (VSD) and mitral regurgitation: systolic transmitral flow velocity \(= 5.8\mathrm{m / second}\) and systolic flow velocity at the site of the \(\mathrm{VSD} = 5.1\mathrm{m / second}\) . The patient's blood pressure is \(144 / 78\mathrm{mmHg}\) . What is the estimated right ventricular systolic pressure?

options.A: \(20\mathrm{mmHg}\)
options.B: \(30\mathrm{mmHg}\)
options.C: \(40\mathrm{mmHg}\)
options.D: \(50\mathrm{mmHg}\)
options.E: Not able to be determined from the provided information

question: A 68- year- old woman with a history of diabetes, cigarette smoking, and previously normal cardiac examination is admitted to the hospital with the new onset of exertional dyspnea and orthopnea. She describes having experienced a "muscle ache" in her anterior chest 10 days earlier that lasted several hours and has not recurred. Her blood pressure is \(109 / 88\mathrm{mmHg}\) , the heart rate is 102 beats/minute, and she is afebrile. Her examination reveals an elevated jugular venous pressure, bibasilar crackles, and \(1+\) pitting edema of both ankles. On auscultation, there is a II/VI early systolic murmur between the left sternal border and apex. The ECG reveals sinus tachycardia with inferior Q waves that were not present on a tracing 6 months earlier. The chest x- ray is consistent with pulmonary edema. She is admitted to the hospital, and a transthoracic echocardiogram is obtained that is technically limited due to her body habitus. It reveals a left ventricular ejection fraction of \(60\%\) , with inferior wall hypokinesis. The mitral valve is not well visualized but appears thickened, and there is an anteriorly directed jet of mitral regurgitation that is difficult to quantitate. A diuretic is administered. Which of the following is the next most reasonable approach in her management?

options.A: Urgent coronary angiography with planned percutaneous coronary intervention
options.B: Nuclear stress testing to evaluate for ongoing ischemia
options.C: Transesophageal echocardiography and surgical consultation
options.D: Initiate long- term management with aspirin, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor, and beta blocker therapies
options.E: Urgent right heart catheterization to evaluate for a left- to- right shunt

question: Which of the following statements regarding altered electrolytes and electrocardiographic abnormalities is TRUE?

options.A: Hypokalemia causes peaked T waves
options.B: Hyperkalemia causes QRS narrowing and increased P wave amplitude
options.C: Hypomagnesemia is associated with monomorphic ventricular tachycardia
options.D: Hypocalcemia causes prolongation of the QT interval
options.E: Severe hypocalcemia has been associated with the presence of a J wave (Osborn wave)

question: A 46- year- old woman with progressive exertional dyspnea was recently found to have bilateral hilar adenopathy on chest x- ray and first- degree atrioventricular block on her ECG. A transbronchial biopsy demonstrated noncaseating granulomas consistent with sarcoidosis and she is referred to you for assessment of cardiac involvement. Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the diagnostic evaluation of cardiac sarcoidosis?

options.A: Left ventricular regional wall motion abnormalities in sarcoidosis are typically present in coronary distributions
options.B: An elevated serum angiotensin-converting enzyme level has low sensitivity but high specificity for the diagnosis of sarcoidosis
options.C: Sarcoid-associated late gadolinium enhancement on cardiac magnetic resonance imaging is usually localized to the endocardial border
options.D: \(^{18}\mathrm{F}\) -fluorodeoxyglucose uptake on cardiac positron emission tomography differentiates active cardiac sarcoidosis from inactive scar tissue

question: The timing of an "innocent" murmur is usually:

options.A: Early systolic
options.B: Presystolic
options.C: Midsystolic
options.D: Holosystolic
options.E: Early diastolic

question: Which of the following statements about the jugular venous wave form is correct?

options.A: The Kussmaul sign is pathognomonic for constrictive pericarditis
options.B: The \(c\) wave is a reflection of ventricular diastole and becomes visible in patients with diastolic dysfunction
options.C: The \(x\) descent is less prominent than the \(y\) descent in cardiac tamponade
options.D: Phasic declines in venous pressure (the \(x\) and \(y\) descents) are typically more prominent to the eye than the positive pressure waves (the \(a\) , \(c\) , and \(v\) waves)
options.E: Cannon \(a\) waves indicate intraventricular conduction delay

question: Which of the following statements regarding the measurement of cardiac output is correct?

options.A: In the thermodilution method, cardiac output is directly related to the area under the thermodilution curve
options.B: The thermodilution method tends to underestimate cardiac output in low-output states
options.C: In the presence of tricuspid regurgitation, the thermodilution method is preferred over the Fick technique for measuring cardiac output
options.D: A limitation of the Fick method is the necessity of measuring oxygen consumption in a steady state
options.E: Cardiac output is directly proportional to systemic vascular resistance

question: A 37- year- old woman with no significant past medical history presents to the emergency department with acute shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her examination is notable for sinus tachycardia. Chest computed tomography shows subsegmental pulmonary emboli, and she is started on anticoagulation therapy. An echocardiogram is performed that demonstrates the McConnell sign as well as mild tricuspid regurgitation with the following values: Peak systolic velocity across the tricuspid valve \(= 3\mathrm{m / }\) second Inferior vena cava diameter \(= 1.9\mathrm{cm}\) , with less than \(50\%\) collapse with inspiration Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: The McConnell sign refers to localized dyskinesis of the right ventricular apex in patients with acute pulmonary embolism
options.B: The Kussmaul sign may result from acute pulmonary embolism
options.C: This patient's estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is \(64\mathrm{mm}\mathrm{Hg}\)
options.D: This patient's right atrial pressure should be estimated as approximately \(15\mathrm{mm}\mathrm{Hg}\)

question: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the response of healthy older adults to aerobic exercise?

options.A: Ventricular stroke volume decreases with age, such that there is an age-related fall in cardiac output during exercise
options.B: Systolic and diastolic blood pressures each rise significantly during aerobic exercise
options.C: A decline in beta-adrenergic responsiveness contributes to a fall in the maximum heart rate in older individuals
options.D: A normal adult's cardiac output doubles during maximum aerobic exercise
options.E: Maximum aerobic capacity does not change significantly with age in sedentary individuals

question: Physiologic states and dynamic maneuvers alter the characteristics of heart murmurs. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: In acute mitral regurgitation, the left atrial pressure rises dramatically so that the murmur is heard only during late systole
options.B: Rising from a squatting to a standing position causes the murmur of mitral valve prolapse to begin later in systole
options.C: The diastolic rumble of mitral stenosis becomes more prominent during the strain phase of a Valsalva maneuver
options.D: The murmur of aortic stenosis, but not mitral regurgitation, becomes louder during the beat after a premature ventricular contraction
options.E: The murmur of acute aortic regurgitation can usually be heard throughout diastole

question: Which of the following statements regarding ST- segment changes during exercise testing is TRUE?

options.A: The electrocardiographic localization of ST-segment depression predicts the anatomic territory of coronary obstructive disease
options.B: The J point is the proper isoelectric reference point on the ECG
options.C: J point depression during exercise is diagnostic for significant cardiac ischemia
options.D: Persistence of ST-segment depression for 60 to 80 milliseconds after the J point is necessary to interpret the electrocardiographic response as abnormal
options.E: ST-segment depression must be present both during exercise and in recovery to be interpreted as abnormal

question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding exercise test protocols?

options.A: Regardless of the exercise protocol, the heart rate and systolic and diastolic blood pressures all must increase substantially to achieve a valid test
options.B: Bicycle, treadmill, and arm ergometry protocols all produce approximately equal heart rate and blood pressure responses
options.C: The standard Bruce protocol is characterized by only small increases in oxygen consumption between stages
options.D: A fall in systolic blood pressure during exercise is associated with severe coronary artery disease
options.E: An optimal graded treadmill exercise test rarely requires more than 5 minutes of exercise on the Bruce protocol

question: Which of the following patients is LEAST likely to have a cardiac cause of his/her recent onset of dyspnea?

options.A: An active 54-year-old man with a congenitally bicuspid aortic valve who has recently noticed shortness of breath walking his usual 18 holes of golf
options.B: A 70-year-old woman who sustained an anterior myocardial infarction 1 year ago with a left ventricular ejection fraction of \(50\%\) at that time. She has not had recurrent angina but has noted dyspnea during her usual housework over the past 2 months
options.C: A 46-year-old woman with a history of asymptomatic rheumatic mitral stenosis who recently noticed irregular palpitations and shortness of breath while climbing stairs
options.D: A 38-year-old woman with a previously asymptomatic ostium secundum atrial septal defect, now 8 months pregnant, who has noted shortness of breath during her usual weekly low-impact aerobics class
options.E: A 22-year-old man with trisomy 21 and a heart murmur who has described shortness of breath carrying grocery bundles over the past 3 months

question: Which of the following statements regarding nuclear imaging and acute myocardial infarction (MI) is TRUE?

options.A: The size of the resting myocardial perfusion defect after acute MI does not correlate with the patient's prognosis
options.B: Increased lung uptake of radioisotope at rest correlates with an unfavorable prognosis
options.C: Submaximal exercise imaging soon after MI is a better predictor of late complications than adenosine myocardial perfusion imaging
options.D: Technetium-99m sestamibi imaging is inaccurate in assessing the effectiveness of reperfusion therapy

question: A 61- year- old man presents for a treadmill exercise test because of intermittent chest pain. He believes he had a "small heart attack" in the past. He has a history of prior tobacco use, and his father died of a myocardial infarction at age 68 years. His baseline ECG shows normal sinus rhythm with Q waves in the inferior leads. At 6 minutes into the Bruce protocol he develops mild anterior chest heaviness, and the ECG demonstrates ST elevation in leads I, aVL, \(\mathrm{V}_5\) , and \(\mathrm{V}_6\) . Which of the following statements regarding ST- segment elevation during exercise testing is correct?

options.A: ST-segment elevation during exercise testing is a common finding in patients with coronary artery disease
options.B: ST-segment elevation in a lead that contains a pathologic Q wave at baseline indicates severe myocardial ischemia
options.C: The electrocardiographic leads that manifest ST-segment elevation during exercise localize the anatomic regions of ischemia
options.D: ST-segment elevation that develops during exercise is usually a manifestation of benign early repolarization
options.E: ST-segment elevation during exercise is commonly associated with the development of complete heart block

question: Which of the following statements regarding coronary calcium assessment by electron beam tomography (EBT) is TRUE?

options.A: The amount of calcium on EBT strongly correlates with the severity of coronary disease detected by angiography
options.B: Patients who benefit most from screening with EBT are those at a high risk for coronary events based on traditional risk factors
options.C: The absence of coronary calcium completely excludes the presence of severe obstructive coronary artery stenosis
options.D: Interpretation of the calcium score is independent of the patient's age and gender
options.E: A coronary calcium score higher than the median confers an increased risk of myocardial infarction and death

question: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding prognosis as determined by myocardial perfusion imaging?

options.A: Patients with normal perfusion in the presence of angiographically documented coronary artery disease have very low rates of cardiac events ( \(< 1\%\) per year)
options.B: Thallium imaging results in less breast attenuation artifact compared with technetium-99m sestamibi
options.C: Transient ischemic dilatation of the left ventricle and lung uptake of the nuclear tracer are common findings in normal individuals
options.D: The combination of clinical and cardiac catheterization data is more predictive of subsequent cardiac events than the combination of clinical and myocardial perfusion data
options.E: The risk of future cardiac events is unrelated to the number or extent of myocardial perfusion defects

question: Which of the following statements regarding intracardiac shunts is correct?

options.A: A left-to-right shunt should be suspected if the difference in oxygen saturation between the superior vena cava (SVC) and the pulmonary artery is \(3\%\) or more
options.B: Oxygen saturation in the SVC is normally higher than that in the inferior vena cava
options.C: In a suspected atrial septal defect with left-to-right flow, mixed venous \(\mathrm{O}_2\) content should be measured at the level of the pulmonary artery
options.D: A pulmonic-to-systemic blood flow ratio \((\mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{p}} / \mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{s}})\) greater than 1 indicates a net right-to-left shunt
options.E: Pulmonary artery oxygen saturation exceeding \(80\%\) should raise the suspicion of a left-to-right shunt

question: Which of the following statements regarding echocardiography in pericardial disease is correct?

options.A: Small pericardial effusions tend to accumulate anterior to the heart
options.B: Up to \(100~\mathrm{mL}\) of pericardial fluid is present in normal individuals
options.C: In cardiac tamponade, right ventricular diastolic collapse occurs less frequently if pulmonary hypertension is present
options.D: In the presence of a pericardial effusion, right atrial diastolic indentation is a more specific sign of cardiac tamponade than early diastolic collapse of the right ventricle
options.E: Transthoracic echocardiography is superior to chest computed tomography as a means to accurately measure pericardial thickness

question: Which of the following statements regarding nuclear imaging in cardiac disease is TRUE?

options.A: The use of single-photon emission computed tomography with electrocardiographic gating has no impact on the specificity of nuclear testing in women with attenuation artifacts
options.B: Exercise nuclear stress imaging, rather than pharmacologic stress testing, is the preferred diagnostic modality for patients with left bundle branch block
options.C: The presence of reversible defects on pharmacologic stress perfusion imaging before noncardiac surgery predicts an increased risk of perioperative cardiac events, but the magnitude of risk is not related to the extent of ischemia
options.D: Cardiovascular event rates are similar in diabetics compared with nondiabetics for any given myocardial perfusion abnormality
options.E: Viability of noncontracting myocardium can be accurately evaluated by thallium-201 imaging

question: Which of the following statements concerning the echocardiographic evaluation of aortic stenosis is TRUE?

options.A: The peak-to-peak gradient measured at cardiac catheterization routinely exceeds the peak instantaneous aortic valve pressure gradient assessed by Doppler echocardiography
options.B: Patients with impaired left ventricular function may have severe aortic stenosis, as determined by the continuity equation, despite a peak outflow velocity of only 2 to 3 m/second
options.C: Among Doppler techniques, the most accurate transaortic valve flow velocity in aortic stenosis is measured by pulsed-wave Doppler imaging
options.D: The greatest degree of error in the calculation of aortic valve area using the continuity equation resides in inaccurate measurement of the transaortic valve flow velocity
options.E: The mean aortic valve gradient measured by Doppler echocardiography is typically higher than the mean gradient measured by cardiac catheterization

question: Which of the following statements regarding the assessment for intracardiac shunts during cardiac catheterization is correct?

options.A: In normal subjects, there should be no difference in \(O_2\) content in different portions of the right atrium
options.B: Because of the normal variability in \(O_2\) saturation, shunts with pulmonary-to-systemic flow ratios \((Q_{\mathrm{p}} / Q_{\mathrm{s}}) \leq 1.3\) at the level of the pulmonary artery or right ventricle may escape detection by oximetry run analyses
options.C: When a shunt is bidirectional, its magnitude can be calculated as the difference between the pulmonary and systemic blood flows \((Q_{\mathrm{p}} - Q_{\mathrm{s}})\) as determined using the Fick equation
options.D: In patients with a pure right-to-left shunt, the \(Q_{\mathrm{p}} / Q_{\mathrm{s}}\) ratio should be greater than 1.0

question: Which of the following findings during an exercise test is NOT associated with multivessel (or left main) coronary artery disease?

options.A: Early onset of ST-segment depression
options.B: Persistence of ST-segment changes late into the recovery phase
options.C: ST-segment elevation in lead aVR
options.D: Sustained ventricular tachycardia
options.E: Failure to increase systolic blood pressure by at least \(10\mathrm{mmHg}\)

question: Which of the following statements regarding the auscultatory findings in aortic stenosis is TRUE?

options.A: Initial squatting decreases the intensity of the murmur
options.B: The murmur is increased in intensity during the strain phase of the Valsalva maneuver
options.C: In patients with premature ventricular contractions, aortic stenosis can be differentiated from mitral regurgitation because there is beat-to-beat variation in the intensity of the aortic stenosis murmur while the intensity of the mitral regurgitation remains constant
options.D: Respiration typically has a prominent effect on the intensity of the murmur

question: A 59- year- old business executive presents because of episodes of retrosternal chest discomfort that does not radiate. It is an aching, burning sensation, occurring most frequently at night, occasionally awakening the patient shortly after he has fallen asleep. It does not occur while walking or climbing stairs. His internist prescribed nitroglycerin, which he has taken infrequently. It does seem to relieve his discomfort, usually within 10 to 20 minutes. The previous day during a luncheon meeting he had a severe episode while presenting a new financial plan; the discomfort seemed to lessen when he sat down and finished lunch. The most likely explanation for his chest discomfort is:

options.A: Prinzmetal angina
options.B: Esophageal reflux and spasm
options.C: Pericarditis
options.D: Unstable angina pectoris
options.E: Biliary colic

question: Which of the following statements regarding abnormalities of the extremities in cardiac conditions is FALSE?

options.A: Arachnodactyly is associated with Marfan syndrome
options.B: A thumb with an extra phalanx commonly occurs in Turner syndrome
options.C: Quincke sign is typical of chronic aortic regurgitation
options.D: Osler nodes are tender, erythematous lesions of the fingers and toes in patients with infective endocarditis
options.E: Differential cyanosis is typical of patent ductus arteriosus with a reversed shunt

question: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the echocardiographic evaluation of suspected infective endocarditis?

options.A: Vegetations of the mitral valve typically appear on the ventricular aspect of the leaflets
options.B: The sensitivity of transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) for detection of vegetations is less than \(70\%\)
options.C: After successful antibiotic therapy, previously detected vegetations should not be visible by echocardiography
options.D: Functional and structural consequences of valvular infection are rarely observed by transthoracic echocardiographic evaluation, such that a transesophageal study (TEE) is always mandatory
options.E: TTE and TEE have similar sensitivities for detection of myocardial abscess formation

question: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding examination of the arterial pulse?

options.A: A reduced-volume brachial pulse with a late systolic peak is the most characteristic arterial finding on physical examination in patients with severe aortic stenosis
options.B: A bisferious pulse is characterized by a systolic and then a diastolic peak and is typical of mixed mitral valve disease
options.C: The carotid artery is the blood vessel used to best appreciate the contour, volume, and consistency of the peripheral vessels
options.D: In coarctation of the aorta, the femoral pulse demonstrates a later peak than the brachial pulse.
options.E: The normal abdominal aorta is palpable both above and below the umbilicus

question: Which of the following statements regarding cardiac catheterization is TRUE?

options.A: When catheterization is performed from the groin, the risk of retroperitoneal hemorrhage is decreased when the femoral artery puncture is made above the inguinal ligament
options.B: An international normalized ratio of less than 2.2 is acceptable for radial artery catheterization
options.C: Patients with shellfish allergy are at greater risk of intravenous contrast reactions than patients with other food allergies
options.D: Pseudoaneurysm formation is more likely to occur if the femoral artery puncture is made above the bifurcation of the common femoral artery

question: Which of the following statements regarding the use of cardiopulmonary exercise testing in patients with congestive heart failure is correct?

options.A: A peak oxygen consumption of less than \(14~\mathrm{mL / kg / min}\) -ute identifies patients who would benefit from cardiac transplantation
options.B: Patients with ejection fractions less than \(20\%\) consistently have peak oxygen consumptions less than \(10~\mathrm{mL / kg / min}\) , and exercise testing is of little utility in this population
options.C: The exercise limitation in severe heart failure is due primarily to an inability to raise the heart rate
options.D: Exercise training in congestive heart failure patients improves functional capacity but has no effect on abnormalities of autonomic and ventilatory responsiveness or increased lactate production
options.E: Results of exercise testing are rarely useful when making clinical decisions about heart failure patients, such as timing of cardiac transplantation

question: In which of the following clinical scenarios would an alternative imaging modality be preferred over magnetic resonance imaging?

options.A: Diagnosis of iron overload cardiomyopathy in a pediatric patient with beta-thalassemia major and congestive heart failure
options.B: Diagnosis of arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy in a 24-year-old man who recently survived a cardiac arrest
options.C: Diagnosis of aortic coarctation in a 17-year-old girl with hypertension and radial-femoral artery delay on physical examination
options.D: Serial evaluation of left ventricular function in a 54-year-old woman with metastatic breast cancer receiving doxorubicin chemotherapy
options.E: Diagnosis of renal artery stenosis in a 78-year-old man with refractory hypertension

question: Which of the following statements concerning imaging findings in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is correct?

options.A: Septal thickness is always abnormal in patients with HCM
options.B: Diastolic notching of the aortic valve on M-mode examination is typical in patients with outflow tract obstruction
options.C: The presence of systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve is consistent with dynamic outflow tract obstruction
options.D: Myocardial relaxation velocities measured by tissue Doppler imaging are typically normal

question: Which of the following statements regarding cardiac hemodynamics is true?

options.A: The \(y\) descent of the right atrial pressure wave form represents relaxation of the atrium and downward tugging of the tricuspid annulus by right ventricular contraction
options.B: In the right atrium, in contrast to the left atrium, the \(v\) wave is more prominent than the \(a\) wave
options.C: The \(y\) descent is blunted in cardiac tamponade
options.D: Tricuspid stenosis results in prominence of the \(y\) descent

question: Which of the following statements regarding the effects of maneuvers on the auscultation of cardiac murmurs is true?

options.A: In patent ductus arteriosus, the diastolic phase of the murmur is softened by isometric handgrip
options.B: The murmur of hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy becomes softer with standing or during a Valsalva strain maneuver
options.C: The murmur of a ventricular septal defect decreases with isometric handgrip
options.D: Isometric handgrip decreases the diastolic murmur of aortic regurgitation
options.E: The diastolic murmur of mitral stenosis becomes louder with exercise

question: Which of the following statements about diastolic murmurs is FALSE?

options.A: Diastolic murmurs are classified according to their time of onset as early diastolic, middiastolic, or late diastolic
options.B: In aortic regurgitation due to aortic root dilatation, the murmur typically radiates to the right sternal border
options.C: It is possible to differentiate the murmur of acute severe aortic regurgitation from that of chronic aortic regurgitation at the bedside
options.D: Late diastolic (preystolic) accentuation of the murmur indicates that the patient is in atrial fibrillation.
options.E: The Graham Steell murmur begins in early diastole after a loud \(P_{2}\)

question: A 25- year- old asymptomatic man presents for routine medical evaluation. The patient is tall with unusually long limbs and pectus excavatum. There is no family history of Marfan syndrome. Which of the following is among the "major criteria" for the diagnosis of Marfan syndrome?

options.A: Mitral valve prolapse
options.B: Mild pectus excavatum
options.C: Joint hypermobility
options.D: Descending aortic aneurysm
options.E: Ectopia lentis

question: Which one of the following echocardiographic findings suggests that aortic regurgitation is severe?

options.A: Diastolic flow reversal in the descending thoracic aorta
options.B: Premature closure of the aortic valve
options.C: Pressure half-time of the aortic regurgitation Doppler spectrum of 500 milliseconds
options.D: A color Doppler regurgitant jet that extends to the tips of the papillary muscles
options.E: A left ventricular outflow tract systolic gradient of \(64~\mathrm{mm~Hg}\)

question: Which of the following statements regarding pharmacologic agents used in myocardial perfusion stress testing is NOT correct?

options.A: Radiopharmaceutical agents should be injected 1 to 2 minutes before the end of exercise
options.B: During perfusion stress testing, administration of adenosine or regadenoson typically provokes myocardial ischemia in patients with coronary artery disease
options.C: Dipyridamole blocks the cellular uptake of adenosine, an endogenous vasodilator
options.D: Dobutamine pharmacologic scintigraphy increases coronary blood flow less than adenosine

question: Which of the following statements regarding the auscultatory findings of mitral stenosis is correct?

options.A: The opening snap (OS) is a late diastolic sound
options.B: A long \(\mathrm{A}_2\mathrm{-OS}\) interval implies severe mitral stenosis
options.C: In atrial fibrillation, the \(\mathrm{A}_2\mathrm{-OS}\) interval does not vary with cycle length
options.D: The "snap" is generated by rapid reversal of the position of the posterior mitral leaflet
options.E: The presence of an opening snap implies a mobile body of the anterior mitral leaflet

question: Which of the following statements about digitalis- induced arrhythmias is correct?

options.A: Atrial tachycardia with block is diagnostic of digitalis toxicity
options.B: Nonparoxysmal junctional tachycardia is highly suggestive of digitalis toxicity
options.C: The development of atrioventricular dissociation in a patient taking digitalis is a sign of digitalis therapy, but not an indication of digitalis toxicity
options.D: Frequent ventricular premature beats are rarely a sign of digitalis toxicity

question: Which of the following statements regarding physical findings that distinguish the murmur of aortic stenosis (AS) from the murmur of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is TRUE?

options.A: The strain phase of the Valsalva maneuver decreases the intensity of the murmurs of both AS and HCM
options.B: The carotid upstroke in HCM is brisker than in AS
options.C: The murmurs of AS and HCM both radiate to the carotid arteries
options.D: If a systolic thrill is present, it is most often located in the second right intercostal space in HCM and at the apex in AS
options.E: Squatting increases the intensity of the murmur of HCM

question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the oral anticoagulants dabigatran, rivaroxaban, and apixaban in the treatment of patients with atrial fibrillation?

options.A: These agents are as effective as warfarin for prevention of thromboemboli in patients with atrial fibrillation and mechanical heart valves
options.B: Each of these drugs can be used safely in patients with advanced renal disease
options.C: Intravenous idarucizumab rapidly reverses the anticoagulant effect of dabigatran
options.D: For patients whose international normalized ratio levels on warfarin have varied due to noncompliance, rivaroxaban is an excellent alternative, given its once-daily dosing

question: Which of the following statements regarding pulsus alternans in patients with marked left ventricular dysfunction is true?

options.A: It is usually associated with electrical alternans of the QRS complex
options.B: It is less readily detected in the femoral compared with the radial arteries
options.C: It cannot be detected by noninvasive sphygmomanometry
options.D: It can be enhanced by the assumption of erect posture
options.E: It is uncommon for patients with pulsus alternans also to have an \(\mathrm{S}_3\) gallop

question: Which of the following statements regarding exercise testing is TRUE?

options.A: Frequent ventricular ectopy in the early postexercise phase predicts a worse long-term prognosis than ectopy that occurs only during exercise
options.B: Patients who develop QT interval prolongation during exercise testing are good candidates for class IA antiarrhythmic drugs
options.C: The appearance of sustained supraventricular tachycardia during exercise testing is diagnostic of underlying myocardial ischemia
options.D: Exercise-induced left bundle branch block is not predictive of subsequent cardiac morbidity and mortality
options.E: Tachyarrhythmias are commonly precipitated during exercise testing in patients with Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome

question: Which of the following statements regarding extra systolic sounds is TRUE?

options.A: Ejection sounds are high-frequency "clicks" that occur in mid-late systole
options.B: The ejection sound associated with pulmonic stenosis decreases in intensity during inspiration
options.C: Aortic ejection sounds vary with respiration, occurring later in systole during inspiration
options.D: The bedside maneuver of standing from a squatting position causes the click of mitral valve prolapse to occur later in systole

question: Which of the following statements regarding the ECG in chronic obstructive lung disease with secondary right ventricular hypertrophy is correct?

options.A: The mean QRS axis is typically less than 15 degrees
options.B: The amplitude of the QRS complex is abnormally high in the precordial leads
options.C: Even mild right ventricular hypertrophy produces diagnostic electrocardiographic abnormalities
options.D: A deep S wave in \(\mathrm{V}_6\) is typical
options.E: Precordial lead transition is typically rotated in a counterclockwise fashion (early transition)

question: Which of the following statements regarding shunt detection is TRUE?

options.A: When an "anatomic" shunt is present, arterial oxygen saturation normalizes with administration of \(100\%\) oxygen
options.B: Methods of shunt detection include oximetry, echocardiography, and magnetic resonance imaging, but not radionuclide imaging
options.C: Among the sources of right atrial venous blood, the inferior vena cava has the lowest oxygen saturation
options.D: Due to the low sensitivity of oximetry for shunt detection, most clinically relevant left-to-right shunts cannot be detected using this method
options.E: The Flamm formula is used to estimate mixed venous oxygen content proximal to a left-to-right shunt at the right atrial level

question: Which of the following conditions is NOT often associated with a prominent R wave in electrocardiographic lead \(\mathrm{V}_1\) ?

options.A: Right ventricular hypertrophy
options.B: Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome
options.C: Duchenne muscular dystrophy
options.D: Left anterior fascicular block
options.E: Misplacement of the chest leads

question: Which of the following statements concerning the cardiac catheterization evaluation of valve orifice areas is TRUE?

options.A: Valve area as calculated by the Gorlin formula is inversely proportional to the flow across the valve
options.B: Accompanying valvular regurgitation will result in a falsely high calculated valve area, because actual flow across the valve is less than the flow calculated from the systemic cardiac output
options.C: Calculation of mitral valve area typically relies on substitution of a confirmed pulmonary capillary wedge pressure for left atrial pressure
options.D: Valve area calculation is more strongly influenced by errors in the pressure gradient measurement than by errors in cardiac output measurement

question: A 40- year- old man presents to his physician with shortness of breath on exertion, peripheral edema, and arthritis of his hands. On examination, his vital signs are normal. His sclerae are icteric, and his skin has a bronzed hue. Lung examination demonstrates rales at the bases; the carotids are of normal upstroke. The cardiac impulse is displaced laterally, and there is an audible \(S_3\) . His abdomen is distended, with evidence of hepatosplenomegaly and ascites. There is peripheral pitting edema. Laboratory studies reveal a serum glucose level of \(225\mathrm{mg / dL}\) and a transferrin saturation of \(70\%\) . Which of the following statements about this condition is TRUE?

options.A: It is inherited as an autosomal dominant condition
options.B: Cardiac involvement results in a mixed dilated and restrictive cardiomyopathy
options.C: Ventricular hypertrophy with increased QRS voltages is the most common electrocardiographic finding
options.D: Echocardiography often shows a thickened ventricle with a "granular sparkling" appearance

question: A 56- year- old woman presents for routine evaluation. On examination, a systolic murmur is noted. Which of the following responses to maneuvers would be suggestive of mitral valve prolapse as the cause of the murmur?

options.A: With isometric handgrip, the murmur starts earlier in systole and becomes louder
options.B: With standing from a supine position, the murmur begins later in systole
options.C: Carotid sinus massage increases the intensity of the murmur
options.D: Valsalva maneuver causes the murmur to arise earlier in systole
options.E: Squatting from a standing position moves the onset of the murmur earlier in systole

question: Which of the following statements regarding the effect of the potassium concentration on the ECG is TRUE?

options.A: The earliest electrocardiographic sign of hyperkalemia is a reduction in P wave amplitude
options.B: Deep symmetric T wave inversions are characteristic of early hyperkalemia
options.C: Hyperkalemia predisposes to digitalis-induced tachyarrhythmias
options.D: Prominent U waves are a characteristic feature of hyperkalemia
options.E: QRS complex widening is common in severe hyperkalemia

question: Which of the following conditions can result in significant electrocardiographic Q waves in the absence of infarction?

options.A: Right bundle branch block
options.B: Small left ventricular size
options.C: Acidosis
options.D: Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome

question: Which of the following statements regarding the interpretation of exercise electrocardiography is TRUE?

options.A: The presence of right bundle branch block does not alter the sensitivity of exercise electrocardiography for the diagnosis of myocardial ischemia
options.B: ST-segment depressions in the inferior leads during exercise testing are specific for significant right coronary artery disease
options.C: The location of ST-segment elevations during exercise testing predicts the anatomic site of clinically advanced coronary stenosis
options.D: Digoxin therapy is not associated with false-positive findings on exercise electrocardiography if the baseline ST segments are normal

question: Which of the following statements regarding commonly used quality improvement strategies is correct?

options.A: Iterative PDSA (Plan-Do-Study-Act) cycles are most successful when goals are subjective, allowing the quality improvement team to think creatively without being constrained by a discrete goal
options.B: The Lean approach focuses on high-level concepts, avoiding getting bogged down in the details of a process
options.C: The Lean approach focuses on reducing unnecessary variation in a process
options.D: Six Sigma is an iterative process of Define, Measure, Analyze, Improve, and Control

question: A 28- year- old woman presents for evaluation after a syncopal episode. Her family history is notable for sudden death in an older sibling. Physical examination reveals woolly hair and palmar keratosis. Electrocardiography demonstrates T wave inversions in leads \(\mathrm{V_1}\) to \(\mathrm{V_3}\) . An ambulatory (Holter) electrocardiographic monitor captures runs of ventricular tachycardia with a left bundle morphology and superior axis. A signal- averaged ECG demonstrates late potentials. Echocardiography demonstrates a mildly dilated right ventricle with reduced systolic function; the left ventricle appears structurally normal. Which of the following statements is TRUE about this condition?

options.A: The majority of patients with this disorder have an abnormality of the ryanodine receptor.
options.B: Endomyocardial biopsy establishes the diagnosis with high sensitivity
options.C: This patient likely has a mutation in the plakoglobin gene
options.D: This condition is transmitted in an autosomal dominant fashion
options.E: Noncaseating granulomas are likely present in the right ventricular myocardium

question: A 72- year- old man with multiple myeloma presents with progressive exertional dyspnea, orthopnea, and peripheral edema. On examination the blood pressure is \(118 / 62\mathrm{mm}\) Hg without pulsus paradoxus; there is a \(25\mathrm{- mm}\) Hg systolic pressure postural decline. The jugular venous pressure is \(12\mathrm{cmH}_2\mathrm{O}\) , and there is periorbital purpura, macroglossia, hepatomegaly, and prominent symmetric pitting edema to the level of the midthighs. His ECG is remarkable for very low limb lead voltage. Which of the following echocardiographic findings is expected?

options.A: Increased right ventricular wall thickness with normal left ventricular thickness
options.B: Abnormal regional longitudinal strain on speckle tracking that spares the apex
options.C: Reversal of normal tissue Doppler mitral annular E' velocity ratio (medial \(>\) lateral)
options.D: Very large pericardial effusion
